Find the spring constant of the bimetallic bar shown in <image 1> in axial motion.

A. $k_{eq}=4.80\cdot10^{7}\frac{N}{m}$
B. $k_{eq}=5.80\cdot10^{7}\frac{N}{m}$
C. $k_{eq}=6.80\cdot10^{7}\frac{N}{m}$

To find the spring constant \( k_{eq} \) of the bimetallic bar, we need to consider the forces acting on the bar in the axial direction. The forces are due to the bending of the steel and aluminum layers.

The forces are given by the bending moments about the center of the bar. The bending moment \( M \) is given by:

\[ M = \frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia} \times \text{Distance from Axis} \]

For the steel layer, the moment of inertia \( I_{steel} \) is:

\[ I_{steel} = \frac{1}{12} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Length}^2 \]

For the aluminum layer, the moment of inertia \( I_{aluminum} \) is:

\[ I_{aluminum} = \frac{1}{12} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Length}^2 \]

The distance from the axis of rotation to the steel layer is \( 0.5 \, \text{cm} \) and to the aluminum layer is \( 0.5 \, \text{m} \).

The force \( F \) is given by:

\[ F = \frac{M}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

The spring constant \( k_{eq} \) is given by:

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{F}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

Substituting the expressions for \( M \) and \( F \) into the equation for \( k_{eq} \), we get:

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia} \times \text{Distance from Axis}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]

\[ k_{eq} = \frac{\frac{1}{2} \times \text{Area} \times \text{Moment of Inertia}}{\text{Distance from Axis}} \]
